Festival under palm trees at foot of Mandalay Hill

Verso: View from Mandalay Hill - Hill has always been covered with shrines but of little importance. A pungyi now called "the Hermit Priest" because he won't live in a Kyaung, went up there some 10 yrs ago and was the founder of their largest shrines on the hill and also has built covered passages approaching hill from 3 sides
Verso: Panorama of Irrawaddy from Mandalay Hill looking west to the river. In distance on right is the Mingun Bell

Verso: Panorama of Kuthodaw Pagoda (on left). Built by Mindon Min. There are 730 small ones around large central one. Atumashi (or incomparable) Pagoda now under construction by the Hermit Priest with public subscriptions
Panorama of Kuthodaw Pagodas, nearer view
Verso: Kuthodaw Pagodas - I counted all of them, and it took six hours for Mr. Noyce to do this.

Verso: Atumashi Pagodas. Incomparable Pagoda (original built Mindon burned down in 1892, probably by Burmans. In the brow of the Buddah which was an image of brick works, was a 40 Karat diamond.) Diamond disappeared.
Close-up of Atumashi Pagoda, person with umbrella in foreground
Burman reading scripture written on rock
Verso: Burman reading scripture on t ablet of stone.
Kyauk Taw Gyi Pagoda and moat from Mandalay Hill
Verso: Kyauk Taw Gyi Pagoda (on right). See page 5 of Noyce Guide book, contains huge sitting Buddha carved out of single block of marble. Completed in 1866. Sculptured by order of King Mindon
Mandalay Hill and East side of moat
Verso: East side of Moat. Looking toward Mandalay Hill.
Mandalay Hill and East side of moat, distant view
Verso: East side of moat + Mandalay Hill. Distant

Verso: Broken bridge in distance known as the Setshin Bridge and was entrance to the Queen's throne. Queen had hers on west and King on east on the "Lion Throne." Queen's throne was the "Lily Throne" emblymatic of beauty and purity. The lily can't be painted.

Verso: Moat originally 25 ft. deep and 100 ft. wide. Was once covered with large pink lotus lilies. After annexation in 1885 the British military authorities destroyed the lotus to prevent malaria. They haven't succeeded yet. Some lotus left. They keep destroying plants over and over. Roots, or suckers, are imbedded in ground and only way to drive out the lotus is to dry moat absolutely. Malaria is not bad here today though. Burmese love the lotus roots as vegetable food. Slightly similar in taste to turnip. Moat and walls were built by town ministers under Mindon. Each man had his own portion. This done to produce spirit of rivalry. Mindon impressed people into the work.
South gate, coolie with petrol tins in foreground
Verso: South Gate - main entrance. Coolie with petrol tins in fore -
Verso: All funerals and embassies passed thru here

Verso: To the east of the palace. Built by Mindon in 1857. There is always a pagoda to the east of every royal palace and facing the palace. On the north side there must also be a capinile or watch tower. Must be built simultaneously. All three must be finished at the same hour all at a given signal in the presence of the reigning king. Mr. H. C. Noyce says Col. Sladan's butler got drunk and went up in pagoda and kicked up a big row and he had to arrest him.

Verso: Royal palace from East, entrance to throne room. This palace was where audiences were held. Was built by Mindon. It was in this palace that Thebaw surrendered. Col. Sladan, who had been political resident in Mandalay, entered before troops. Mindon Min built a church and school for the church of Eng. for Dr. Marlas and sent the princes there including Thebaw. King and Queen Thebaw and Supyalat seldom ever left palace. Queen only went out 3 times. Afraid of assassins.
Royal Palace from the East with troops in the foreground

Verso: Eastern view of Royal Palace. Built of teals from the Shiveli forest in the Katha district where the finest teak comes from. Roofed with corrugated iron. British government has put in new foundations of concrete but lightning or earthquake might bring it down. Not a big earthquake here since 1839 which split the great Mingun Pagoda. It is one of the finest symmetrical buildings in Burma. Rises very gracefully from base. For carving the Queen's monastery built by Supyalat is finest example of carving altho not so symmetrical. In 1885 monastery was [?] of gold.
Royal Palace from the East, distant view

Verso: These cannon were presented by the French government to the Burmese government in days of King Pagan Min (the famous cock fighter whose capital was Amurapura.) He was defeated by his younger bro. Mindon who brought them to Mandalay. Mindon, after defeating his bro., treated him with great respect and enabled him to live royally to his death. Mindon was greatest of late Burman rulers. To please Queen Victoria he encouraged Christianity and built Christ Church. No war between Burma and Britain in his day. He sent an embassy to London to tell Queen Victoria he had done this meritorious act on her behalf. In return the Queen sent out a marble fount for Baptismal purposes which stands in the church today.

Verso: Central tomb is where King Mindon was buried. Tomb on right is Queen Ain ByerMahyin, mother of Thebaw. (Owner of the White House) Tomb on left is where Queen Sinbyoo May Yin, (which means owner of a white elephant), mother of Supyalat. She was the intriguer and responsible for all the massacres in Oct. 1879, including 50 or 60 of the royal house. Supyalat sided with her mother but was only about 17 yrs. old although queen at the time. All of Thebaw's step bros. wanted to be king so it was done in defense of throne.
Thebaw Kyaung with wife of Ou Chit Pwe dancing, Lowell Thomas with pith helmet, umbrella and cane

Verso: King Thebaw's Kyaung- built by Mindon and where his son Thebaw rec'd his theological training. He was there until he was selected for the throne. It was done by lot but there was trickery on part of Supyalat's mother and she worked things so that he was the lucky man. He was not the eldest son and not even the son of the favorite queen. Thebaw was about 21 when he became king. Before then he was unknown. He was a handsome Burman, with round face, heavy mustache, and very heavy set. Not much intelligence doing. He let his mother in law and wife run things. Supyalat overrode king's ministers. There was talk among the ministers of Thebaw being too young and weak. Supyalat heard of this and put out all the ministers but one and he was the Prince minister who agreed to kneel before her golden foot. But he was the only high Burman official who tried to prevent the 3rd Burmese war. He had been to Eng. and knew Eng's power but others wouldn't listen. British gave him a pension until he died. Thebaw in monastery 2 or 3 years. British used it as a church of England for troops. Now going to ruin which is most unfortunate.
Thebaw Kyaung with wife of Ou Chit Pwe dancing, Lowell Thomas with pith helmet, umbrella and cane

Verso: The great image of Buddah in Akyab was taken by force from the Arakonese and brought to Mandalay, in 1784, although the town of Mandalay was not in existence in those days.
Mingun Bell, Mrs. Frances Ryan Thomas with back to camera, woman squatting and man at right
